questions.Q: The side $$a$$ of a square, is measured to be $$(12.4 \pm 0.1)$$ cm. The perimeter $$P$$ of the square including the uncertainty is:
questions.E: Given that $$P=a+a+a+a$$, the perimeter is $$49.6\,\text{cm}$$. The absolute uncertainty in $$P$$ is: $$\Delta P = \Delta a+\Delta a+\Delta a+\Delta a=4\Delta a=4(0.1\,\text{cm})=0.4\,\text{cm}$$. Thus, $$P = (49.6 \pm 0.4)\,\text{cm}$$.

questions.Q: The percentage uncertainty in the quantity $$Q = p âˆ’ q$$, where $$p = 538.7 \pm 0.3$$ and $$q = 537.3\pm0.5$$ is:
questions.E: Given that $$Q = p\pm q$$ the uncerntainty in $$Q$$ is $$\Delta Q =\Delta p+\Delta q$$. Thus, $$Q=538.7- 537.3=1.4$$ and $$\Delta Q= 0.3 + 0.5=0.8$$. The percentage uncertainty in $$Q$$ is $$\frac{\Delta Q}{Q}\times 100=\frac{0.8}{1.4}\times 100=57.1\,\%$$.

questions.Q: The sides of a rectangle are measured to be $$a = 2.5\,\text{cm} \pm \,0.1\,\text{cm}$$ and $$b =  5.0\,\text{cm} \pm \,0.1\,\text{cm}$$. The area $$A$$ of the rectangle.is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=ab\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q}=\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}+\frac{\Delta b}{b_0}$$, where $$a=a_0 \pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0 \pm \Delta b\\$$ The fractional uncertainty in $$a$$ is: $$\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}=\frac{0.1}{2.5}=0.04=4\,\%\\$$The fractional uncertainty in $$b$$ is: $$\frac{\Delta b}{b_0}=\frac{0.1}{5.0}=0.02=2\,\% \\$$ Thus, the fractional uncertainty in the area is $$0.04 + 0.02 = 0.06$$ or $$6\,\% \\$$ The area $$A_0$$ is: $$A_0 = 2.5 \times 5.0 = 12.5\,\text{cm}^2$$ and $$\frac{\Delta A}{A_0}=0.06\\$$ $$\Rightarrow \Delta A = 0.06 \times12.5 = 0.75 \,\text{cm}^2\\$$ Hence, $$A = 12.5 \,\text{cm}^2 \pm 0.8\,\text{cm}^2$$ (the final absolute uncertainty is quoted to 1 sinificant figure.).

questions.Q: The magnitudes of two forces are measured to be $$F_1=120\, \pm 5\,\,\text{N}$$ and $$F_2=60\, \pm 3\,\,\text{N}$$. The value of $$F_1+F_2$$, giving the uncertainty is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=a\pm b \Rightarrow \Delta Q=\Delta a +\Delta b$$, where $$a=a_0 \pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0 \pm \Delta b\\$$ Thus, $$\\ F=F_1+F_2=(F_{10}\pm \Delta F_1)+(F_{20}\pm \Delta F_2) = (F_{10}+F_{20})\pm (\Delta F_1+\Delta F_2)=(120+60)\pm (\Delta F_1+\Delta F_2)= 180\, \pm 8\,\,\text{N}$$

questions.Q: The magnitudes of two forces are measured to be $$F_1=120\, \pm 5\,\,\text{N}$$ and $$F_2=60\, \pm 3\,\,\text{N}$$. The value of $$F_1-F_2$$, giving the uncertainty is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=a\pm b \Rightarrow \Delta Q=\Delta a +\Delta b$$, where $$a=a_0 \pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0 \pm \Delta b\\$$ Thus, $$\\ F=F_1-F_2=(F_{10}\pm \Delta F_1)-(F_{20}\pm \Delta F_2) = (F_{10}-F_{20})\pm (\Delta F_1+\Delta F_2)=(120-60)\pm (\Delta F_1+\Delta F_2)= 60\, \pm 8\,\,\text{N}$$

questions.Q: The radius $$r$$ of a circle is measured to be $$2.4\, \pm 0.1\,\,\text{cm}$$. The uncertainty in the perimeter of the circle is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=\alpha x^\beta \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \beta\frac{\Delta x}{x_0}$$, where $$\alpha$$ and $$\beta$$ are constants. In our case: $$Q \Rightarrow P=2\pi r$$, $$\alpha=2\pi$$ and $$\beta=1$$ and $$x\Rightarrow r$$. So, $$\frac{\Delta P}{P_0}= \frac{\Delta r}{r_0}= \frac{0.1}{2.4}=0.04$$, where $$P_0=2\pi r_0=2\pi (2.4\,\text{cm})=15.1\,\text{cm}$$. Thus, $$\Delta P=P_0\frac{\Delta r}{r_0}=15.1\,\text{cm}\times 0.04=0.6\,\text{cm}$$

questions.Q: A mass is measured to be $$m=4.4\, \pm 0.2\,\,\text{kg}$$ and its speed is measured to be $$v=18\, \pm 2\,\,\text{m/s}$$. The kinetic energy $$E_k$$ of the mass is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=A a^\alpha b^\beta \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha \frac{\Delta a}{a_0}+\beta \frac{\Delta b}{b_0}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$, $$\beta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b\\$$ In our case: $$\\Q \Rightarrow E_k=\frac{1}{2}mv^2$$, $$A=\frac{1}{2}$$, $$a\Rightarrow m$$, $$b\Rightarrow v$$, $$\alpha=1$$ and $$\beta=2 \\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta E_k}{E_{k0}}= \frac{\Delta m}{m_0}+\beta \frac{\Delta v}{v_0}=\frac{\Delta 0.2}{4.4}+2\times \frac{2}{18}= 0.267$$ and $$E_{k0}=\frac{1}{2}\times(4.4\,\text{kg})\times(18\,\text{m/s})^2=712.8\,\text{J}\\ $$ Thus, $$\\ \Delta E_k=0.267\times 712.8\,\text{J}=190.8\,\text{J}\\ $$ To one significant figure, the uncertainty is $$\Delta E = 200 = 2 \times 10^2\,\text{J}$$; that is $$E = (7\pm 2) \times 10^2\,\text{J}$$

questions.Q: The volume of a cylinder of base radius $$r$$ and height $$h$$ is given by $$V = \pi r^2h$$. The volume is measured with an uncertainty of $$4\,\%$$ and the height with an uncertainty of $$2\,\%$$. The percentage uncertainty in the radius is:
questions.E: We must first solve for the radius to get $$r=\sqrt{\frac{V}{\pi h}}$$ Now, recall that if $$Q=A \frac{a^\alpha }{b^\beta} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q}= \alpha \frac{\Delta a}{a}+\beta \frac{\Delta b}{b}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$ and $$\beta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b$$. In our case: $$\\Q \Rightarrow r=\sqrt{\frac{V}{\pi h}}$$, $$A=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}$$, $$a\Rightarrow V$$, $$b\Rightarrow h$$, $$\alpha=\beta=\frac{1}{2} \\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta r}{r_0}\times 100\,\%= \frac{1}{2}\frac{\Delta V}{V_0} \times 100\,\% +\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta h}{h_0}\times 100\,\%=\frac{1}{2}(\frac{\Delta V}{V_0}+\frac{\Delta h}{h_0})\times 100\,\%=  \frac{1}{2}(4+2)\,\%= 3\,\%$$

questions.Q: The diameter of a steel ball was determined by using a ruler to measure four similar balls in a row. The positions on the ruler scale were measured to be $$X=1.0\pm 0.2\,\text{cm}$$ and $$Y=5.0\pm 0.2\,\text{cm}$$ Out of the following measurements the one that express the value of a ball diameter with its associated uncertainty is:
questions.E: Let $$S=S_0\pm \Delta S=Y-X$$ where $$\Delta S=\Delta X+\Delta Y=0.2\,\text{cm}+0.2\,\text{cm}=0.4\,\text{cm} $$ and $$S_0=Y_0-X_0=5.0\,\text{cm}-1.0\,\text{cm}=4.0\,\text{cm}\\$$ Thus, $$\\S=S_0\pm\Delta S=(4.0\pm 0.4)\,\text{cm}\\$$ The ball diameter is $$D=D_0\pm \Delta D$$ where $$D_0=\frac{S_0}{4}=\frac{4.0\,\text{cm}}{4}=1.0\,\text{cm}\\$$ $$\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta D}{D_0}=\frac{\Delta S}{S_0}=\frac{0.4\,\text{cm}}{4.0\,\text{cm}}=0.1 \\ \therefore \Delta D=D_0(0.1)=1.0\,\text{cm}\times 0.1=0.1\,\text{cm}\\$$ Hence, $$D=D_0 \pm \Delta D=(1.0 \pm 0.1)\,\text{cm}$$

questions.Q: The mass of a block was measured as $$10\pm 1\,\text{g}$$  and the volume was measured as $$5.0\pm 0.2\,\text{cm}^3$$. The density of the body with the associated uncertainty is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=A\frac{a}{b} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q}= \frac{\Delta a}{a}+\frac{\Delta b}{b}$$, where $$A$$ is a constant and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b\\$$ In our case:$$\\Q \Rightarrow \rho=\frac{m}{V}$$, $$A=1$$, $$a=m$$, $$b=V\\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho_0}=\frac{\Delta m}{m_0}+\frac{\Delta V}{V_0}=\frac{1\,\text{g}}{10\,\text{g}}+\frac{0.2\,\text{cm}^3}{5\,\text{cm}^3}=0.1+0.04=0.14\\$$ and $$\rho_0=\frac{m_0}{V_0}=\frac{10\,\text{g}}{5\,\text{cm}^3}=2.0\,\text{g/cm}^3\\$$ Thus, $$\Delta \rho=\rho_0\times 0.14=2.0\,\text{cm}^3\times 0.14=0.28\,\text{g/cm}^3\approx 0.3\,\text{g/cm}^3$$. The density is $$\rho=\rho_0\pm \Delta \rho=(2.0 \pm 0.3)\,\text{g/cm}^3$$

questions.Q: The side $$a$$ of a cube, is measured to be $$(4.0 \pm 0.1)$$ cm. The volume of the cube with the associated uncertainty is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=Aa^\alpha \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a}$$, where $$A$$ is a constant and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a \\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow V=a^3$$, $$A=1$$, $$\alpha=3\\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta V}{V_0}=3\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}=3\frac{0.1\,\text{cm}}{4\,\text{cm}}=0.075\\$$ and $$V_0=a_0^3=(4.0\,\text{cm})^3=64\,\text{cm}^3\\$$ Thus, $$\Delta V=V_0\times 0.075=64\,\text{cm}^3\times 0.075=4.8\,\text{cm}^3 \approx 5\,\text{cm}^3\\$$ The volume is $$V=V_0\pm \Delta V=(64 \pm 5)\,\text{g/cm}^3$$

questions.Q: A resistor is marked as having a value of $$4.7\,\Omega\pm 2\%$$. The power $$P$$ dissipated in the resistor is given in terms of the electric current $$i$$ as $$P=Ri^2$$. If $$i=(2.50\pm 0.05)\,\text{mA}$$, the percentage uncertainty in the value of $$P$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=Aa^\alpha b^\beta \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a}+\beta\frac{\Delta b}{b}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$ and $$\beta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a \\$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b \\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow P=Ri^2$$, $$A=1$$, $$\alpha=1$$, $$\beta=2$$, $$a\Rightarrow R$$ and $$b\Rightarrow i \\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta P}{P_0}=\frac{\Delta R}{R_0}+2\frac{\Delta i}{i_0}= \frac{2}{100}+2\frac{0.05}{2.50} =0.06=6\,\%$$

questions.Q: The acceleration of free fall $$g$$ was to be determined by measuring the periode of oscillation $$T$$ and the length $$L$$ of a simple pendulum and using the formula $$g=\frac{4\pi^2L}{T^2}$$. In the experiment, the uncertanties in measuring  $$L$$ and $$T$$ were estimated to be $$4\,\%$$ and $$1\,\%$$ respectively. The uncertainty in $$g$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=A\frac{a^\alpha}{b^\beta} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}+\beta\frac{\Delta b}{b_0}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$ and $$\beta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a \\$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b \\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow g=\frac{4\pi^2 L}{T^2}$$, $$A=4\pi^2$$, $$\alpha=1$$, $$\beta=2$$, $$a\Rightarrow L$$ and $$b\Rightarrow T \\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta g}{g_0}=\frac{\Delta L}{L_0}+2\frac{\Delta T}{T_0}= \frac{4}{100}+2\frac{1}{100} =0.06=6\,\%$$

questions.Q: The mass and dimensions of a block were measured to be $$m=(25.0\pm 0.1)\,\text{g}$$, $$L=(5.00\pm 0.01)\,\text{cm}$$, $$W=(2.00\pm 0.01)\,\text{cm}$$ and $$H=(1.00\pm 0.01)\,\text{cm}$$ respectively. The density of the block was calculated to be $$2.50\,\text{g/cm}^3$$. The uncertainty in the density is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=A\frac{a^\alpha}{b^\beta c^\gamma d^\delta} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a}+\beta\frac{\Delta b}{b}+\gamma\frac{\Delta c}{c}+\delta\frac{\Delta d}{d}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$, $$\beta$$, $$\gamma$$ and $$\delta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$, $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b$$, $$c=c_0\pm \Delta c$$ and $$d=d_0\pm \Delta d\\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow \rho=\frac{m}{LWH}$$, $$A=1$$, $$\alpha=\beta=\gamma=\delta=1$$, $$a\Rightarrow m$$, $$b\Rightarrow L$$, $$c\Rightarrow W$$ and $$d\Rightarrow H\\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho_0}=\frac{\Delta m}{m_0}+\frac{\Delta L}{L_0}+\frac{\Delta W}{W_0}+\frac{\Delta H}{H_0}= \frac{0.1}{25.0}+\frac{0.01}{5.00}+\frac{0.01}{2.00}+\frac{0.01}{1.00} =0.021\\ \therefore \Delta \rho=0.021\times2.50\approx \pm 0.05\,\text{g/cm}^3 $$

questions.Q: The time taken for a body, dropped from the top of a tower, to fall to the ground was given as $$(2.0\pm 0.1)\,\text{s}$$. The acceleration of free fall was taken as $$10\,\text{m/s}^2$$ The appropriate way to report the calcaulated height of the tower is:
questions.E: The time it takes for a body to fall a distance $$h$$ is given by $$t=\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\therefore h=\frac{1}{2}gt^2$$ Recall that if $$Q=Aa^\alpha \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}$$ where $$A$$ and $$\alpha$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a \\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow h=\frac{1}{2}gt^2$$, $$A=\frac{1}{2}g$$, $$\alpha=2$$, $$a\Rightarrow t\\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta h}{h_0}=2\frac{0.1}{2.0}= 0.1\\$$  and $$\\h_0=\frac{1}{2}gt_0^2=\frac{1}{2}(10\,\text{m/s}^2)(2.0)^2=20\,\text{m} \\ \therefore \Delta h=h_0\times 0.1=20\,\text{m}\times 0.1=2\,\text{m}$$

questions.Q: In a experiment to determine the density of a metal ball, the uncertainty in the measurement of the mass was to be $$1\,\%$$ and that of its diameter was $$3\,\%$$ The uncertainty in the density of the ball is:
questions.E: The dendity is given by $$\rho=\frac{m}{V}=\frac{m}{\frac{4}{3}\pi (\frac{D}{2})^3}=\frac{m}{\frac{1}{6}\pi D^3}=\frac{6m}{\pi D^3}$$. Recall that if $$Q=A\frac{a^\alpha}{b^\beta} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}+\beta\frac{\Delta b}{b_0}$$ where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$ and $$\beta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b \\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow \rho=\frac{6m}{\pi D^3}$$, $$A=\frac{6}{\pi}g$$, $$\alpha=1$$, $$\beta=3$$, $$a\Rightarrow m$$ and $$b\Rightarrow D\\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho_0}\times 100\,\%=\frac{\Delta m}{m_0}\times 100\,\%+3\frac{\Delta D}{D_0}\times 100\,\%= 1\,\%+3(3\,\%)=10\,\%\\$$

questions.Q: The external diameter $$d_1$$ and internal diameter $$d_2$$ of a metal tube were reported as $$(64\pm 2)$$ mm and $$(47\pm 1)$$ mm respectively. The percentage uncertainty in $$d_1-d_2$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=a\pm b\Rightarrow \Delta Q= \Delta a+\Delta b$$ where $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b \\$$ In our case:$$ \\Q \Rightarrow d= d_{1}- d_{2}=d_0\pm \Delta d$$, $$a\Rightarrow d_1$$ and $$b\Rightarrow d_2\\$$ Where, $$\\ d_0=d_{10}-d_{20}=64\,\text{mm}-47\,\text{mm}=17\,\text{mm}\\$$ and $$\\ \Delta d=\Delta d_1+ \Delta d_2= 2\,\text{mm}+1\,\text{mm}=3\,\text{mm}\\$$ Thus, $$\\ \frac{\Delta d}{d_0}\times 100\,\%=\frac{3}{17}\times 100=17.6\approx 18\,\%$$

questions.Q: The velocity of a liquid in a pipe was to be determined by measuring the force on a small disc placed in the center of the pipe with its plane perpendicular to the flow. The equation relating $$F$$ and $$v$$ is given by $$F=kv^2$$ where $$k$$ is a constant. The velocity had to be determined with a maximum uncertainty of $$1\,\%$$ The maximum percentage uncertainty in measuting the force $$F$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=Aa^\alpha \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}$$, where $$A$$ is a constant and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a \\$$ In our case:$$ \\ Q \Rightarrow F=kv^2$$, $$A=k$$, $$a\Rightarrow v$$ and  $$\alpha=2\\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta F}{F_0}\times 100\,\%=2\frac{\Delta v}{v_0}\times 100\,\%=2\times(1\,\%)=2\,\%$$

questions.Q: The volume of a cylinder of height $$h$$ and radius $$r$$ is given by the expression $$V=\pi r^2 h$$. In a particular experiment, $$r$$ is determined from measurements of $$V$$ and $$h$$. The percentage uncertainty in $$V$$ is $$\pm 5\%$$ and that in $$h$$ is $$\pm 2\%$$. The percentage uncertainty in $$r$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=A\frac{a^\alpha}{b^\beta} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}+\beta\frac{\Delta b}{b_0}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$, $$\beta$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$, $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b \\$$ In our case: $$ \\ Q \Rightarrow r=\sqrt{\frac{V}{\pi h}}$$, $$A=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\pi}}$$, $$\alpha=\beta=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}$$, $$a\Rightarrow V$$ and $$b\Rightarrow h \\$$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta r}{r_0}\times 100\,\%=\frac{1}{2}\frac{\Delta V}{V_0}\times 100\,\%+\frac{1}{2}\frac{\Delta h}{h_0}\times 100\,\%= \frac{1}{2}\times (5\,\%)+\frac{1}{2}\times (1\,\%)=3.5\,\% \approx 4\,\% $$

questions.Q: The radius $$r$$ of a sphere is measured to be $$22.7\, \pm 0.2\,\,\text{cm}$$. The uncertainty in the surface area of the sphere is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$Q=A x^\alpha \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}$$, where $$A$$ and $$\alpha$$ are constants and $$a=a_0 \pm \Delta a \\$$ In our case: $$\\ Q \Rightarrow S=4\pi r^2$$, $$A=4\pi$$ and $$\alpha=2$$ and $$a\Rightarrow r \\ $$ So, $$\\ \frac{\Delta S}{S_0}= 2\frac{\Delta r}{r_0}= 2\frac{0.2\,\text{cm}}{22.7\,\text{cm}}=0,01762$$, where $$S_0=4\pi r_0^2=4\pi (22.7\,\text{cm})^2=6475.32511\,\text{cm}^2 \\$$. Thus, $$\\ \Delta S=S_0(0.017621)=114.1017\,\text{cm}^2\approx 114.1\,\text{cm}^2$$

questions.Q: The true value of a of quantity $$x$$ is $$x_0$$. In an experiment, the quantity is measured  many times and the number $$N$$ of readings giving a value $$x$$ is plotted against $$x$$. Out of the following graphs, the one that shows measurements that are precise but not accurate is:
questions.E: B

questions.Q: The centripetal force is given by $$F = \frac{mv^2}{r}$$. The mass is measured to be $$2.8 \pm 0.1\,\text{kg}$$, the velocity $$14 \pm 2\,\text{m/s}$$ and the radius $$8.0 \pm 0.2\,\text{m}$$; the force on the mass, including the uncertainty is:
questions.E: Recall that given $$Q=A\frac{a^\alpha b^\beta}{ c^\gamma} \Rightarrow \frac{\Delta Q}{Q_0}= \alpha\frac{\Delta a}{a_0}+\beta\frac{\Delta b}{b_0}+\gamma\frac{\Delta c}{c_0}$$, where $$A$$, $$\alpha$$, $$\beta$$ and $$\gamma$$ are constants and $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$, $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b$$ and $$c=c_0\pm \Delta c\\ $$ In  our case $$Q \Rightarrow F=\frac{mv^2}{r}$$ and $$A=1$$, $$\alpha=1$$, $$\beta=2$$, $$\gamma=1$$, $$a\Rightarrow m$$, $$b\Rightarrow v$$ and $$c\Rightarrow r\\$$Thus, $$\\ \frac{\Delta F}{F_0}=\frac{\Delta m}{m_0}+2\frac{\Delta v}{v_0}+\frac{\Delta r}{r_0} \\ \therefore \Delta F= F_0\times \Big( \frac{\Delta m}{m_0}+2\frac{\Delta v}{v_0}+\frac{\Delta r}{r_0}\Big )= \Big( \frac{2.8\,\text{kg}\times (14\,\text{m/s})^2}{8.0\,\text{kg}}\Big) \times \Big(\frac{0.1}{2.8}+2\frac{2}{14}+\frac{0.2}{8.0}\Big)= 24 \,\text{N}\\$$So, $$F=(69 \pm 24)\,\text{N}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows part of a ruler and an object, the length of the object expressing the uncertainty is:
questions.E: The ruler has graduations separated by 0.1 cm. We are confident that the position of the right end is greater than 17.8 cm and smaller than 17.9 cm. The true value is somewhere between these bounds. The average of the lower and upper bounds is $$17.85\,\text{cm}$$ and so we quote the measurement as $$(17.85 \pm 0.05)\,\text{cm}$$. Notice that the uncertainty of $$\pm 0.05\,\text{cm}$$ is half the smallest width on the ruler.

questions.Q: The figure shows part of a ruler and an object, the length of the object expressing the uncertainty is:
questions.E: The ruler has graduations separated by 0.2 cm. We are confident that the position of the right end is greater than $$24.4\,\text{cm}$$ and smaller than 24.6 cm. The true value is somewhere between these bounds. The average of the lower and upper bounds is $$24.5\,\text{cm}$$ and so we quote the measurement as $$(24.5 \pm 0.1)\,\text{cm}$$. Notice that the uncertainty of $$\pm 0.1\,\text{cm}$$ is half the smallest width on the ruler.

questions.Q: The figure shows part of a ruler and an object, the length of the object expressing the uncertainty is:
questions.E: The ruler has graduations separated by 0.1 cm. We are confident that the position of the right end is greater than $$23.1\,\text{cm}$$ and smaller than 23.2 cm. The true value is somewhere between these bounds. The average of the lower and upper bounds is $$23.15\,\text{cm}$$ and so we quote the measurement as $$(23.15 \pm 0.05)\,\text{cm}$$. Notice that the uncertainty of $$\pm 0.05\,\text{cm}$$ is half the smallest width on the ruler.

questions.Q: The figure shows part of a ruler and an object, the length of the object expressing the uncertainty is:
questions.E: The ruler has graduations separated by 0.2 cm. We are confident that the position of the right end is greater than $$53.4\,\text{cm}$$ and smaller than 53.6 cm. The true value is somewhere between these bounds. The average of the lower and upper bounds is $$53.5\,\text{cm}$$ and so we quote the measurement as $$(53.5 \pm 0.1)\,\text{cm}$$. Notice that the uncertainty of $$\pm 0.1\,\text{cm}$$ is half the smallest width on the ruler.

questions.Q: The diagram shows the temperature of a liquid before and after heating. The best estimate for the temperature increase of the liquid is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$P=a\pm b\Rightarrow \Delta P=\Delta a+ \Delta b$$ where $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b\\$$. In our case $$Q \Rightarrow T$$ and $$a\Rightarrow T_1$$ and $$b\Rightarrow T_2\\$$ The temperature before heating is $$T_1=(24.3\pm 0.5)\,^\circ C$$ and the temperature after heating is $$T_2=(68.5\pm 0.5)\,^\circ C\\$$ Notice that the uncertainty of $$\pm 0.5\,^\circ C$$ is half the smallest width on the scale. $$\\$$ Thus, $$\Delta T=\Delta T_1+\Delta T_2=0.5\,^\circ C+0.5\,^\circ C=1\,^\circ C$$ Notice, the result has one significant digit! $$\\$$ On the other hand, the temperature increase is $$\\ T=T_2-T_1=68.5\,^\circ C-24.3\,^\circ C=44.2\,^\circ C\\$$ Thus, the temperature increase considering the uncertainty is: $$(44 \pm 1)\,^\circ C\\$$ Notice that we have to round off $$44.2\,^\circ C$$ to $$44\,^\circ C$$ as the uncertainty has one significant digit.

questions.Q: The diagram shows the temperature of a liquid before and after cooling. The best estimate for the temperature decrease of the liquid is:
questions.E: Recall that if $$P=a\pm b\Rightarrow \Delta P=\Delta a+ \Delta b$$ where $$a=a_0\pm \Delta a$$ and $$b=b_0\pm \Delta b\\$$. In our case $$Q \Rightarrow T$$ and $$a\Rightarrow T_1$$ and $$b\Rightarrow T_2\\$$ The temperature before cooling is $$T_1=(73.4\pm 0.5)\,^\circ C$$ and the temperature after cooling is $$T_2=(25.7\pm 0.5)\,^\circ C\\$$ Notice that the uncertainty of $$\pm 0.5\,^\circ C$$ is half the smallest width on the scale. $$\\$$ Thus, $$\Delta T=\Delta T_1+\Delta T_2=0.5\,^\circ C+0.5\,^\circ C=1\,^\circ C$$ Notice, the result has one significant digit! $$\\$$ On the other hand, the temperature decrease is $$\\ T=T_1-T_2=73.4\,^\circ C-25.7\,^\circ C=47.7\,^\circ C\\$$ Thus, the temperature increase considering the uncertainty is: $$(48 \pm 1)\,^\circ C\\$$ Notice that we have to round off $$47.7\,^\circ C$$ to $$48\,^\circ C$$ as the uncertainty has one significant digit.

questions.Q: The image of an object a distance $$a$$ from a lens is formed at a distance $$b$$ from the lens, where $$a$$ and $$b$$ are related through the equation $$\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=\frac{1}{f}$$ and $$f$$ is the focal length of the lens. If $$a=(50\pm 3)\,\text{mm}$$, $$b=(200\pm 5)\,\text{mm}$$, the value of $$f$$ and the associated uncertainty is: (Hint: $$\Delta \frac{1}{x} =\frac{\Delta x}{x^2}$$)
questions.E: Plugging values of $$a=50\,\text{mm}$$ and $$b=200\,\text{mm}$$ in the equation $$\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=\frac{1}{f}$$ and clearing $$f$$ we have $$f=40\,\text{mm}\\$$ Using $$\Delta \frac{1}{x} =\frac{\Delta x}{x^2}\\ \Delta \frac{1}{f}=\Delta \Big(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}\Big)= \Delta \frac{1}{a}+\Delta \frac{1}{b} \Leftrightarrow \\ \frac{\Delta f}{f^2}=\frac{\Delta a}{a^2}+\frac{\Delta b}{b^2}\\ \therefore \Delta f=f^2\Big( \frac{\Delta a}{a^2}+\frac{\Delta b}{b^2}\Big)\\=(40\,\text{mm})^2\Big( \frac{3\,\text{mm}}{(50\,\text{mm})^2}+\frac{5\,\text{mm}}{(200\,\text{mm})^2}\Big) \\=2.12\,\text{cm}\\$$Thus, $$\\ f=(40\pm 2)\,\text{mm}$$ (to one significant figure)
